bibl.title: Decree from Gaboon
Despatches from U.S. Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888

div1.p: Monsieur the Commandant Superior of the French settlements, West Coast of Africa

We the undersigned merchants established at Gaboon having been made acquirable with the circular which was addressed to us by your order on the 16th of this month, and in accordance with your invitation to us to forward to you our observations on the occasion of our visit to you on the 24th of September last on the subject of the circular dated the 21st of the same month.
Have the honor to state to you that which follows.

The mercantile community of Gaboon was painfully impressed on learning by the announcement contained in your first circular that the mother country having thought proper to reduce the local
expenses you should deem it necessary to make it support the amount of this reduction, commencing by causing us to pay for licences, which we consider to be very high if compared to those paid in France where trade is so much more important than here.

That moreover when we established ourselves at Gaboon we were far from forseeing that so sudden a change would one day come upon us and in a manners so burdensome we were so much the further from supposing it, seeing that the country is one of the poorest and most unhealthy of the Coast of Africa.

With regard to the second circular relative to the duties to be imposed at a later date upon the Importations and Exportations of merchandise we can only repeat to you that which we have said before with regard to the licences that the mercantile community is totally unable to bear any of
these expenses, and this you will perfectly understand by the statement which we to forward to you.
Barwood the principal return cargo does not pay freight, this is easily seen, the present selling price in France being 75 to 85 francs at most per ton.
Ebony is but of slow sale, after being kept a long time in warehouses and consequently after heavy expences.
India Rubber becomes daily scarcer, and even may be said to be disappearing entirely, besides this it sustains great loss of weight, it is nevertheless the most important article.
Ivory is purchased at a rate here than in Europe, consequently the profit denied from it is very small, and consists only in the made in the goods.
Beeswax, this product is so scarce that it may be considered as exhausted.

To all this we have to add that living becomes harder daily, fresh provisions being wanting so to speak, moreover we cannot do otherwise than draw your attention to the enormous losses which we sustain by the frequent plundering of our boats, and this in spite of your good will. As to the trust given to the natives, we will not enlarge on that subject, and yet you are perfectly aware that those advances once made may be considered as three fourth lost.

That circular also containes several articles relative to the keeping of our Books, on this lead we will beg you to notice that in a country where one can remain but a short time, and is often ill, it is impossible to keep accounts as regularly as in France.

In addition, profiting by this opportunity, we think that we ought to draw your attention to the fact, that the formalities to be fulfilled
becomes daily more complicated, thus we are obliged before commencing the unloading or leading of a vessel to obtain a permit at the cost of a franc. There appears to us necessity for the existence of this permit in a country where until now, the authorities having nothing to gain thereby has never occupied itself with this kind of operation this measure occasioning some time a delay cannot but be prejudicial to us.

Hoping Monsieur the Commandant that you will be pleased to take into consideration the different observations which we have the honor to address to you, and that in your high sense of Justice you will recognise the impossibility of insisting upon the execution of the said circular of Sept 21st and Nov 16th.

We have the honor to be
Your very humble and very obedient Servants.

(signed)
E Pilastus Victoria & Dubarry
Robert Kirkwood E. Hannah
William Latta John L. Wookey
Johs Thormahlin.
